en_second_half: across the room. It was an inconceivably stupid thing to have done. But, he realized, even in his panic he had not wanted to smudge the creamy paper by shutting the book while the ink was wet.
en_results: The words seemed to leap out at him, a defiant cry that echoed the countless others he had scribbled in secret over the years, a declaration of rebellion against the all-pervasive gaze of the Party.
en_results_raw: The words seemed to leap out at him, a defiant cry that echoed the countless others he had scribbled in secret over the years, a declaration of rebellion against the all-pervasive gaze of the Party. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he wondered if anyone had seen it, if the telescreens had caught a glimpse of the forbidden phrase. He quickly turned the diary shut, his heart racing with the familiar fear of being discovered, of being dragged away to the Ministry of Love for his transgression. But as he turned to leave, he hesitated, his hand still on the doorknob. Something was off, something that made him pause and look back at the diary, his mind racing with the consequences of his actions.

en_results_raw: of dead and wounded, the telescreen flickered and a face appeared on the screen, a face that made Winston's heart sink. It was the face of O'Brien, his old comrade and friend, now a high-ranking member of the Thought Police. Winston's mind racing, he tried to remember the last time he had seen O'Brien, and the circumstances of their parting, but his memories were hazy and unclear. The face on the screen seemed to be watching him, its eyes boring into his very soul, and Winston felt a shiver run down his spine as O'Brien's voice spoke, his words dripping with menace and foreboding. "Winston Smith," the voice said, "you are summoned to the Ministry of Love for questioning. You are to report immediately." The screen flickered and went dark, leaving Winston staring at the blank wall in a state of shock and terror, his mind reeling with the implications of what was to come.

The cold air of the room made him shiver, and he rubbed his hands together to warm them up. The telescreen, still blaring its ear-piercing whistle, seemed to be mocking him, reminding him of the long day of drudgery that lay ahead. Winston shuffled over to the small kitchen area, where a single cup of black coffee was waiting for him, brewed from the rationed coffee beans he had managed to scrounge from the black market. He poured the coffee into a chipped mug and took a sip, feeling the bitter taste course through his veins. The clock on the wall read 7:17, and he knew he had to hurry if he was going to make it to the Ministry of Truth on time. He grabbed his worn-out briefcase and headed out the door, joining the throngs of other workers streaming into the streets, all of them with their faces set in determined expressions, their eyes fixed on the telescreens that lined the buildings, broadcasting the latest propaganda messages from the Party. Se preguntó si alguien más en la ciudad estaría escuchando ese silbido, si alguien más se sentiría como él, como si estuviera esperando algo, pero no supiera qué. La telepantalla siguió silbando durante otros diez minutos, hasta que finalmente se detuvo. La habitación se quedó en silencio, excepto por el ruido de la nevera en la cocina. Su instructora, una mujer joven y animosa, le observaba con una sonrisa amable, pero Winston sabía que no podía engañarla. Ella había visto su expresión de concentración y sabía que algo no iba bien. Sin embargo, no decía nada, y Winston se sentía agradecido por su discreción. Continuó con la clase, intentando mantener la compostura, pero su mente seguía vagando por el pasado, tratando de encontrar una pista, cualquier pista, que le permitiera recuperar la memoria perdida. La clase terminó finalmente, y Winston se despidió de su instructora con una sonrisa forzada, sintiendo que había fracasado en su intento de recuperar el pasado. Pero no se rindió. Sabía que tenía que seguir intentándolo, que tenía que encontrar una forma de recuperar la memoria que le había sido arrebatada. Y así, se dirigió a casa, decidido a seguir investigando, a seguir buscando cualquier cosa que pudiera ayudarle a recuperar la memoria que le había sido robada.

en_results_raw: The tunnels beneath their house, the sound of the sirens and the rumble of the explosion growing fainter with each step. His father's grip on his hand was tight, but not painful, and Winston felt a sense of security in it. They walked in silence, the only sound being the creaking of the stairs and the heavy breathing of the people around them. As they descended, the air grew thick with the smell of dust and smoke, and Winston could feel the weight of the earth above them. His father finally stopped at a door, pushed it open, and pulled Winston through it, into a narrow corridor lined with rows of bunk beds. The room was dimly lit, the only light coming from a few flickering candles, and the air was stale and musty. Winston's father led him to a small bed, and they sat down together, listening to the sounds of the raid above them. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the occasional groan of a building collapsing or the distant rumble of an explosion. Winston's father put his arm around him, holding him close, and Winston felt a sense of comfort in his presence. As the hours passed, the sounds of the raid grew fainter, and the silence became more oppressive. Winston's father tried to reassure him, telling him that they were safe, that they would be okay, but Winston couldn't shake the feeling of unease that had settled in his stomach. He looked up at his father, trying to read his expression, but his face was a mask of calm, his eyes fixed on some point in the distance. Winston's mind began to wander, thinking about the world above, about the people who were suffering, about the destruction that was being wrought. He felt a sense of helplessness, a feeling that he was trapped, that he couldn't do anything to stop the war. His father's grip on his hand tightened, and he looked down at Winston, his eyes filled with a deep sadness. "It's going to be okay, son," he said, his voice low and reassuring. "We'll get through this." Winston nodded, trying to believe him, but the feeling of unease lingered, a constant reminder of the war that raged above them.

A medida que se acercaba a la edad adulta, comenzó a cuestionar la normalidad de la guerra y a preguntarse si era posible que hubiera un mundo sin ella. La noticia de que su país estaba a punto de enviar tropas a un nuevo teatro de operaciones lo sacudió de su rutina, y se preguntó qué les esperaba a ellos en ese lugar desconocido. ¿Sería un nuevo frente de batalla, o una oportunidad para la paz? Solo el tiempo lo diría. Mientras tanto, él se preparaba para lo peor, sabiendo que la guerra era su destino. La incertidumbre lo rodeaba, pero él estaba listo para enfrentarla, con la mano de su padre en la suya y la voz de su madre en su corazón. La guerra era su realidad, pero también era su oportunidad para hacer la diferencia. Y él estaba dispuesto a aprovecharla.

en_results_raw: be set aside for the cinema, and he had been meaning to go to the pictures for weeks, but somehow never got around to it. The queue for the ticket office was already snaking out of the foyer, and Winston groaned inwardly, wondering if he would have to wait for hours to get in. He glanced at his watch, noting that it was already past seven, and the film he wanted to see was about to start. The person in front of him in the queue was a young woman, dressed in a bright yellow coat, who seemed to be arguing with the ticket seller about the price of a ticket. Winston listened with half an ear, his mind wandering to the film he was about to see, a romantic comedy that he had heard was hilarious. He had been looking forward to it all week, and was eager to forget his troubles for a few hours. As he waited, he noticed a group of people behind him, chatting and laughing, and he felt a pang of envy. They seemed to be a group of friends, out for a night on the town, and Winston couldn't help but feel a little left out. He wondered if he would ever be able to afford to go out like that, or if he would always be stuck in this mundane routine. The woman in front of him finally finished her argument, and the ticket seller handed her a ticket, and Winston moved forward, his turn next. He handed over his money, and took his ticket, feeling a sense of relief wash over him. He made his way to the cinema, his heart racing with excitement, and his mind still wandering to the film he was about to see.

en_first_half: He remembered how once he had been walking down a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices—women’s voices—had burst from a side street a little way ahead. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy
en_second_half: things, but cooking pots of any kind were always difficult to get. Now the supply had unexpectedly given out. The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats! Why was it that they could never shout like that about anything that mattered?
en_results: output>The vendor, a wizened old man with a scowl on his face, was standing amidst the chaos, his arms crossed and a look of exasperation etched on his features. The women, their faces twisted in anger and frustration, were shouting and pointing at the tin saucepans, which were indeed flimsy and of poor quality. One of them, a stout woman with a red scarf tied around her head, was brandishing a saucepan in the air, her voice rising to a crescendo as she accused the vendor of selling them "rubbish." es_first_half: Recordó Winston una vez que había dado un paseo por una calle de mucho tráfico cuando oyó un tremendo grito múltiple. Centenares de voces, voces de mujeres, salían de una calle lateral. Era un formidable grito de ira y desesperación, un tremendo ¡O-o-o-o-oh! Winston se sobresaltó terriblemente. ¡Ya empezó! ¡Un motín!, pensó. Por fin, los proles se sacudían el yugo; pero cuando llegó al sitio de la aglomeración vio que una multitud de doscientas o trescientas mujeres se agolpaban sobre los puestos de un mercado callejero con expresiones tan trágicas como si fueran las pasajeras de un barco en trance de hundirse. En aquel momento, la desesperación general se quebró en inmumerables peleas individuales. Por lo visto, en uno de los puestos habían estado vendiendo sartenes de lata. Eran utensilios muy malos, pero los
es_second_half: cacharros de cocina eran siempre de casi imposible adquisición. Por fin, había llegado una provisión inesperadamente. Las mujeres que lograron adquirir alguna sartén fueron atacadas por las demás y trataban de escaparse con sus trofeos mientras que las otras las rodeaban y acusaban de favoritismo a la vendedora. Aseguraban que tenía más en reserva. Aumentaron los chillidos. Dos mujeres, una de ellas con el pelo suelto, se habían apoderado de la misma sartén y cada una intentaba quitársela a la otra. Tiraron cada una por su lado hasta que se rompió el mango. Winston las miró con asco. Sin embargó, ¡qué energías tan aterradoras había percibido él bajo aquella gritería! Y, en total, no eran más que dos o tres centenares de gargantas. ¿Por qué no protestarían así por cada cosa de verdadera importancia?

en_results_raw: Staff, discussing the details of a clandestine operation to disrupt the supply lines of the Allied forces. The men, all seasoned operatives, had been tasked with gathering intelligence on the Eurasian military's movements and identifying potential vulnerabilities in their defenses. They had spent several days in the region, gathering information and making contact with local assets, before being extracted back to Canada via a pre-arranged extraction route. However, their mission had been compromised when they were intercepted by a group of Soviet border patrol units, who had been tipped off by a mole within the Eurasian General Staff. The men had been taken into custody and subjected to intense interrogation, during which they had eventually cracked under the pressure and confessed to their involvement in the operation. The Eurasian authorities had been eager to make an example of the men, and had put them on trial for espionage and treason. The trials had been a sham, with the outcome predetermined, and the men had been found guilty and sentenced to life imprisonment. Despite their harsh treatment, the men had refused to reveal any further information about their mission or their handlers, and had maintained their silence even in the face of torture and coercion. The Eurasian authorities had been left frustrated and embarrassed by the men's refusal to cooperate, and had been forced to keep their involvement in the operation a secret. The incident had been a major blow to the Eurasian intelligence community, and had highlighted the need for greater security and counter-intelligence measures to prevent similar breaches in the future. The Eurasian General Staff had been forced to re-evaluate their entire intelligence gathering operation, and had implemented new protocols to prevent similar incidents from occurring again. The men's bravery and loyalty had been an inspiration to their fellow operatives, and had cemented their place in the annals of espionage history. The incident had also raised questions about the morality of espionage and the ethics of using human lives as pawns in the game of international politics. As the years went by, the men's story would become a cautionary tale about the dangers of espionage and the importance of secrecy in the world of international relations.

es_results_raw: GRU, la inteligencia militar rusa, y habían recibido instrucciones para reunirse con un contacto que les proporcionaría información sobre un proyecto secreto de armas biológicas. Sin embargo, al llegar a la cita, descubrieron que se trataba de una trampa y que el contacto era en realidad un doble agente que trabajaba para la CIA. Los tres personajes, que se habían conocido en una misión anterior en Afganistán, se dieron cuenta de que estaban en peligro y decidieron huir de inmediato. Lograron escapar de Siberia y regresar al aeródromo secreto en el Canadá, pero no sin antes haber sido perseguidos por agentes rusos y americanos que intentaban capturarlos. Una vez de regreso en el aeródromo, se reunieron con su jefe, un hombre llamado Alexander, que les explicó que el proyecto de armas biológicas era solo una tapadera para una misión mucho más grande y peligrosa. Alexander les dijo que su misión era infiltrarse en un laboratorio secreto en Corea del Norte, donde se estaba desarrollando un arma química capaz de destruir ciudades enteras. Los tres personajes se prepararon para la misión, sabiendo que su vida dependía de su éxito. Mientras tanto, en la CIA y el GRU, los agentes que los habían perseguido en Siberia estaban siendo investigados por sus superiores, quienes comenzaban a sospechar que algo no iba bien en la operación. La situación se estaba volviendo cada vez más compleja y peligrosa, y los tres personajes sabían que debían ser cuidadosos para no ser descubiertos. La misión en Corea del Norte se acercaba, y ellos estaban listos para enfrentar lo que viniera. Pero ¿qué les esperaba en el laboratorio secreto? ¿Serían capaces de completar su misión y regresar a casa, o se convertirían en las próximas víctimas de la guerra de espionaje? Solo el tiempo lo diría.

en_first_half: FROM SOMEWHERE at the bottom of a passage the smell of roasting coffee—real coffee, not Victory Coffee—came floating out into the street. Winston paused involuntarily. For perhaps two seconds
en_second_half: he was back in the half-forgotten world of his childhood. Then a door banged, seeming to cut off the smell as abruptly as though it had been a sound.
en_results: completion>—two seconds, he stood there, his heart beating rather faster as the smell grew stronger, and then he moved on, his eyes scanning the crowded
en_results_raw: completion>—two seconds, he stood there, his heart beating rather faster as the smell grew stronger, and then he moved on, his eyes scanning the crowded street. The smell was coming from a small café tucked away between a second-hand bookstore and a tailor's shop. Winston had never noticed it before, but now that he had, he couldn't help but feel a pang of curiosity. He quickened his pace, his mind racing with possibilities. Could it be that there was still a place in the city where one could get a decent cup of coffee, a place that defied the Party's efforts to control every aspect of life? He pushed open the door and stepped inside, his eyes adjusting to the dim light within. The café was small, with only a handful of tables and a counter where a barista was expertly brewing a pot of coffee. Winston took a seat at the counter, his eyes fixed on the barista as he waited for his turn. The smell of roasting coffee was intoxicating, and he felt a sense of excitement building inside him. He ordered a cup and took a sip, closing his eyes in rapture as the flavors danced on his tongue. It was like nothing he had tasted in years, a true coffee that was rich and full-bodied, not the bitter swill they served at the Victory Café. Winston felt a sense of hope rising up inside him, a sense that there was still a glimmer of freedom in this oppressive city. He sat there for a while, savoring the coffee and the moment, feeling like he had stumbled upon a secret that the Party didn't want him to know. But as he finished his cup and prepared to leave, he noticed a figure watching him from across the room. It was a woman with piercing green eyes and long, curly brown hair, and she seemed to be staring right through him. Winston felt a shiver run down his spine as their eyes met, and he quickly looked away, wondering if he had imagined the whole thing. But as he turned to leave, he felt a gentle touch on his arm, and he turned back to see the woman smiling at him. "You're a long way from home, aren't you?" she said, her voice low and husky. Winston nodded, feeling a sense of trepidation. "I'm just passing through," he said, trying to sound nonchalant. The woman nodded, her eyes never leaving his face. "I know a place where you can get a good cup of coffee," she said, her voice dripping with suggestion. Winston's heart skipped a beat as he wondered what she meant, and whether he should trust her. He hesitated for a moment, and then nodded, following her out of the café and into the unknown.

en_second_half: street took a sharp turn and then ended in a flight of steps which led down into a sunken alley where a few stallkeepers were selling tired-looking vegetables. es_results_raw: un edificio antiguo, con paredes de ladrillo rojo y una fachada de piedra, que parecía haber sido construido en un estilo arquitectónico que databa de siglos atrás. La fachada estaba adornada con una gran puerta de madera tallada, que parecía haber sido diseñada para ser una entrada principal, pero que ahora se encontraba cerrada con una cadena y un candado. La calle estaba desierta, excepto por un grupo de niños que jugaban en la esquina, y un anciano que se sentaba en un banco, mirando hacia la fachada del edificio con una expresión de nostalgia en su rostro. La atmósfera era tranquila, pero Winston notó que había algo en el aire que no parecía del todo natural. La sensación de que había estado allí antes se volvió más intensa, y comenzó a sentir que estaba a punto de recordar algo importante. De repente, un viento suave sopló por la calle, y el anciano se levantó del banco y se acercó a Winston. "¿Puedo ayudarte, joven?", le preguntó con una voz suave y amable. Winston se sintió sorprendido, pero respondió con una sonrisa forzada, "No, gracias, estoy solo buscando algo". El anciano asintió con la cabeza y se alejó, pero Winston notó que lo miraba con una expresión curiosa. La sensación de que había estado allí antes se volvió más intensa, y comenzó a sentir que estaba a punto de recordar algo importante. De repente, un recuerdo le vino a la mente, y se dio cuenta de que había estado en esa calle antes, muchos años atrás, cuando era un niño. Recordó haber estado con su abuelo, que le había llevado a ese edificio y le había contado historias sobre su pasado. El recuerdo era vago, pero lo suficientemente claro como para que Winston supiera que era real. Se sintió emocionado y confundido al mismo tiempo, y se preguntó qué había pasado con su abuelo y por qué no recordaba nada de eso hasta ahora. La calle parecía haberse vuelto más oscura, y la atmósfera más tensa. Winston se sintió como si estuviera a punto de descubrir un secreto importante, pero no sabía qué era ni cómo encontrarlo. Se quedó allí, mirando hacia el edificio antiguo, sintiendo que estaba a punto de descubrir algo que cambiaría su vida para siempre.

Sólo podemos leerlo en los libros, y lo que dicen los libros puede no ser verdad. Me gustaría saber su opinión sobre esto. Los libros de historia dicen que la vida anterior a la Revolución era por completo distinta de la de ahora. Había una opresión terrible, injusticias, pobreza... en fin, que no puede uno imaginar siquiera lo malo
es_second_half: que era aquello. Aquí, en Londres, la gran masa de gente no tenía qué comer desde que nacían hasta que morían. La mitad de aquellos desgraciados no tenían zapatos que ponerse. Trabajaban doce horas al día, dejaban de estudiar a los nueve años y en cada habitación dormían diez personas. Y a la vez había algunos individuos, muy pocos, sólo unos cuantos miles en todo el mundo, los capitalistas, que eran ricos y poderosos. Eran dueños de todo. Vivían en casas enormes y suntuosas con treinta criados, sólo se movían en autos y coches de cuatro caballos, bebían champán y llevaban sombrero de copa.

en_first_half: Winston sat back against the window sill. It was no use going on. He was about to buy some more beer when the old man suddenly got up and shuffled rapidly into the stinking urinal at the side of the room. The extra half-liter was already working on him. Winston sat for a minute or two gazing at his empty glass, and hardly noticed when his feet carried him out into the street again. Within twenty years at the most, he reflected, the huge and simple question, “Was life better before the Revolution than it is now?” would have ceased once and for all to be answerable. But in effect it was unanswerable even now, since the few scattered survivors
en_second_half: from the ancient world were incapable of comparing one age with another. They remembered a million useless things, a quarrel with a workmate, a hunt for a lost bicycle pump, the expression on a long-dead sister’s face, the swirls of dust on a windy morning seventy years ago; but all the relevant facts were outside the range of their vision. They were like the ant, which can see small objects but not large ones. And when memory failed and written records were falsified—when that happened, the claim of the Party to have improved the conditions of human life had got to be accepted, because there did not exist, and never again could exist, any standard against which it could be tested.

La gente de su generación había crecido en un mundo donde la Revolución había sido un hecho consumado, y su única experiencia de la vida antes de ella era a través de los libros y las historias de sus padres y abuelos. Winston se preguntó si alguna vez se enteraría de la verdad sobre aquella época, o si la historia sería siempre una serie de rumores y leyendas. Mientras caminaba por la calle, se fijó en un grupo de niños que jugaban en la acera. Eran demasiado jóvenes para recordar la época anterior a la Revolución, pero estaban aprendiendo a vivir en un mundo donde la libertad y la individualidad eran conceptos tabú. Winston se sintió un poco triste al pensar en la vida que les esperaba, y se preguntó si algún día podrían conocer un mundo donde la gente pudiera vivir sin la constante vigilancia del Partido. La idea le parecía tan lejana, tan imposible, que se sintió tentado a reírse de sí mismo por soñar con algo tan utópico. Pero algo en su interior le decía que no debía rendirse, que debía seguir buscando la verdad y luchando por un mundo mejor. Mientras caminaba, se fijó en un cartel que colgaba en la pared de un edificio cercano. Decía "La verdad es la libertad" en letras grandes y negras. Winston se detuvo un momento a leer las palabras, y sintió un escalofrío en la espalda. ¿Era posible que alguien hubiera escrito eso? ¿O era solo una broma, un intento de subversión? Winston no lo sabía, pero se sintió atraído por el cartel, como si estuviera llamando a su atención. Se acercó un poco más y leyó las palabras una vez más. La verdad es la libertad. ¿Era eso todo? ¿Era eso lo que él estaba buscando? Winston se quedó allí un momento, pensando en la pregunta, y luego siguió caminando. No sabía qué hacer a continuación, pero sabía que no podía seguir ignorando el cartel. Tenía que seguir investigando, tenía que seguir buscando la verdad. Y así, con un sentido de propósito renovado, se dirigió hacia el centro de la ciudad, hacia el corazón del Partido, donde la verdad y la libertad parecían estar más lejos que nunca.

en_results_raw: The tiny interior of the shop was in fact uncomfortably full, but there was almost nothing in it of the slightest value. The floor-space was very restricted, because all round the walls were stacked innumerable dusty picture frames. In the window there were trays of nuts and bolts, worn-out chisels, penknives with broken blades, tarnished watches that did not even pretend to be working, and a few old, yellowed books with their pages torn and dog-eared. The air was thick with the smell of dust and decay, and the faint scent of something else, something sweet and acrid, that seemed to cling to the very walls themselves. Behind the counter, a small, bespectacled man with a look of quiet desperation in his eyes hunched over a workbench, his hands moving with a slow, mechanical precision as he attempted to repair a broken clock. The clock's face was cracked and faded, its hands stuck in a perpetual 3:47, and the man's efforts seemed to be making little progress. Despite the clutter and disarray, the shop seemed to be a place of quiet industry, where the owner was driven by a stubborn determination to keep going, no matter how futile his efforts might seem. The sound of ticking clockwork and the soft scratching of the man's tools filled the air, a soothing background noise that seemed to lull the shop into a state of suspended animation. As I stood there, frozen in the doorway, the man looked up and caught my eye, his expression a mixture of curiosity and wariness, and for a moment, I felt a shiver run down my spine as our gazes met. The shop seemed to hold its breath, waiting to see what I would do next, and I felt a strange sense of connection to this strange, forgotten place, a sense that I had stumbled into something much larger than myself.

es_results_raw: que parecían haber sido abandonados en la calle, y en el suelo, entre los objetos apilados, había una gran variedad de cosas que parecían haber sido utilizadas en alguna época para fines artísticos, como moldes de arcilla rotos, pinceles gastados, y un gran número de papeles con dibujos y esbozos de diferentes artistas, algunos de ellos firmados con nombres que no reconocí. La atmósfera de la tienda era extraña, como si estuviera congelada en el tiempo, y el dueño, un hombre anciano con gafas y un bigote canoso, parecía estar esperando a alguien, o a algo, con una mirada fija en la puerta. De repente, escuché un ruido detrás de mí y me di la vuelta para ver a una joven con un bolso grande y un bolígrafo en la mano, que se acercaba a la caja registradora con una sonrisa en el rostro.

en_results_raw: have been a decorative item of some sort, perhaps a vase or a container for perfume. As he turned it over in his hand, he noticed the intricate etchings that covered its surface, a delicate dance of lines and patterns that seemed to shimmer in the dim light of the shop. The shopkeeper, a wizened old man with a kind face, watched him with a knowing glint in his eye, as if he could see the fascination growing in Winston's mind. "A rare find, that one," he said, his voice low and gravelly. "Not many people would appreciate its beauty, but you, my friend, seem to have an eye for the unusual." Winston felt a surge of pride at the shopkeeper's words, and he couldn't help but wonder what story this mysterious object might tell if it could speak. He imagined it sitting on a dusty shelf in some long-forgotten mansion, waiting for the right person to come along and appreciate its unique charm. As he turned to leave, the shopkeeper called out to him, "You know, I think I might have something else that would interest you." He disappeared into the back room, leaving Winston to wonder what other treasures he might uncover. The air in the shop seemed to vibrate with the promise of discovery, and Winston felt his heart racing with excitement as he waited for the shopkeeper to return. He glanced around the shop, taking in the rows of dusty jars and the shelves lined with strange and exotic objects, each one more fascinating than the last. The shopkeeper emerged with a small, leather-bound box in his hands, and Winston's eyes widened as he opened it to reveal a collection of antique clockwork mechanisms, their intricate gears and springs glinting in the dim light. "This one's a real treasure," the shopkeeper said, his eyes shining with enthusiasm. "A clockwork bird, from the early days of the Industrial Revolution. It's said to have been crafted by one of the greatest clockmakers of the time." Winston's mind reeled as he gazed at the delicate mechanisms, his fingers itching to take it apart and understand its inner workings. The shopkeeper smiled, as if reading his mind. "I think you'll find it's just the thing to complement your new acquisition," he said, nodding towards the etched glass object still clutched in Winston's hand. Winston's eyes widened as he realized the shopkeeper was right – the clockwork bird and the etched glass seemed to be meant to be together, a pair of artifacts from different eras that somehow fit together perfectly. He felt a sense of wonder and excitement wash over him as he realized the possibilities that lay before him, and he knew that this was just the beginning of a journey into a world of discovery and adventure.

Lo que le atraía de él no era tanto su belleza como el aire que tenía de pertenecer a una época completamente distinta de la actual. Aquel cristal no se parecía a ninguno de los que él había visto. Era de una suavidad extraordinaria, con reflejos acuosos. Era el coral doblemente atractivo por su aparente inutilidad, aunque
es_second_half: Winston pensó que en tiempos lo habían utilizado como pisapapeles. Pesaba mucho, pero afortunadamente, no le abultaba demasiado en el bolsillo. Para un miembro del Partido era comprometedor llevar una cosa como aquélla. Todo lo antiguo, y mucho más lo que tuviera alguna belleza, resultaba vagamente sospechoso. El dueño de la tienda pareció alegrarse mucho de cobrar los cuatro dólares. Winston comprendió que se habría contentado con tres e incluso con dos.

en_results_raw: used for some purpose other than its current one, perhaps as a storage space or a makeshift office. The air was thick with dust, and a faint scent of old books wafted through the air, mingling with the smell of dampness that seeped through the walls. Winston's eyes adjusted slowly to the dim light, and he made out the shapes of old armchairs, a worn sofa, and a large, wooden desk in the center of the room. The desk was cluttered with papers, pens, and a small, leather-bound book, its cover worn and cracked with age. Winston's gaze wandered to the book, and he felt a sudden pang of curiosity. He approached the desk, his footsteps echoing off the walls, and reached out a hand to touch the book. As he did, he noticed a small, hidden compartment in the desk drawer, partially concealed by a tattered piece of fabric. Winston's heart quickened with excitement as he carefully pulled out the compartment, revealing a stack of yellowed letters tied with a faded ribbon. The letters were addressed to a person named "Evelyn," and the postmarks dated back decades. en_results_raw: limb, yet still he felt a pang of sympathy for the man. The enemy, a skilled fighter with a scar above his left eyebrow, sneered at Winston, his eyes flashing with a mix of anger and contempt. Winston, however, couldn't help but notice the way the man's gaze faltered for a split second as he glanced at the injured creature, and in that moment, he saw a glimmer of something almost like humanity. The creature, a young woman with a mangled arm, whimpered softly, her eyes fixed on Winston with a desperate plea for help. Winston's heart went out to her, and he found himself hesitating, unsure of what to do next. The enemy, sensing his momentary weakness, took a step closer, his hand on the hilt of his sword. Winston knew he had to act quickly, but his mind was clouded by the conflicting emotions that churned within him. He thought of his own life, of the people he loved, of the danger that lurked in every corner of this treacherous land. And yet, he couldn't shake the feeling that he was being given a rare opportunity to choose between his own survival and the survival of another human being. The enemy's eyes seemed to be daring him to make a move, to choose between his own self-preservation and the well-being of the injured woman. Winston's hand instinctively went to the hilt of his own sword, but he hesitated, unsure of what to do. The woman's eyes locked onto his, and he felt a jolt of electricity run through his body. He knew he had to make a decision, and fast, before the enemy took advantage of his hesitation.

en_results_raw: The rusty gate that hung crookedly on its hinges, and the willow tree that leaned out over the stream, its long branches trailing in the water. It was a place he had seen before, a place he had been to as a child, but the memories of it had long been buried beneath the layers of his adult life. As he stood there, the scene began to take shape in his mind, and he felt a sense of nostalgia wash over him. He remembered the countless hours he had spent playing in this very field, chasing after butterflies and watching the clouds drift lazily by. The memories were hazy, but they were there, and they brought with them a sense of longing and a deep connection to the past. Winston's eyes wandered back to the present, and he saw that Julia was watching him, a look of curiosity on her face. He turned to her, and they exchanged a quiet, wordless understanding, a sense that they were both thinking the same thing: that this was a place of freedom, a place where they could be themselves, without the weight of the world bearing down on them. They stood there for a moment, suspended in time, the only sound the gentle rustling of the leaves in the breeze.

A medida que caminaban, el olor a hierba fresca y el canto de los pájaros se mezclaban con el silencio de la mañana. Winston recordó haber estado allí antes, aunque no podía precisar cuándo. La sensación de familiaridad crecía en él, y su mente comenzó a trabajar con la información que tenía. De repente, una imagen le vino a la mente: una tarde de verano, un picnic con su familia, su hermano menor jugando en el sendero, su madre sonriendo mientras preparaba la comida. La imagen se desvaneció tan rápido como había surgido, pero dejó un rastro de nostalgia en su corazón. Winston se detuvo y miró a Julia, que caminaba a su lado, con una expresión de curiosidad en su rostro. "¿Te parece que hemos estado aquí antes?", le preguntó, pero Julia no respondió. Continuaron caminando, sumidos en sus pensamientos, hasta que llegaron a un claro en el bosque. Allí, en el centro del claro, había una gran roca, cubierta de musgo y líquenes. La roca parecía ser el punto focal del claro, y Winston se sintió atraído hacia ella. Se acercó a la roca, sintiendo la energía del lugar, y se sentó en su superficie. Julia se sentó a su lado, y juntos se quedaron en silencio, mirando el paisaje que los rodeaba. El sol brillaba en el cielo, y el aire estaba lleno de la fragancia de las flores silvestres. Era un momento de paz, un momento de conexión con la naturaleza y con sí mismos. Pero, en el fondo de su mente, Winston sabía que no era un momento de paz total. Había algo que lo inquietaba, algo que lo hacía sentir que estaban siendo observados. Se volvió hacia Julia, pero ella seguía mirando hacia adelante, sin darse cuenta de su inquietud. Winston se levantó de la roca y se puso a caminar de nuevo, con Julia a su lado. El sendero se curvaba hacia la izquierda, y Winston se sintió atraído hacia él. "Vamos", le dijo a Julia, "creo que debemos seguir adelante". Julia asintió, y juntos continuaron su camino, sumidos en la incertidumbre de lo que los esperaba.

es_results_raw: que es periodista y me dijo que tuviera cuidado con la forma en que se escriben las noticias, porque la forma en que se presentan los hechos puede influir en la percepción de los lectores. Me pareció una observación interesante y me hizo reflexionar sobre la importancia de la redacción en la comunicación periodística. Algunas veces, la forma en que se presentan los hechos puede ser tan importante como los hechos en sí mismos, ya que puede influir en la forma en que los lectores perciben la información y la interpretan. Por ejemplo, si se presentan los hechos de manera objetiva y neutral, los lectores pueden formarse una opinión más clara y precisa sobre el tema, mientras que si se presentan de manera sesgada o tendenciosa, pueden formarse una opinión distorsionada. En este sentido, la redacción es un elemento clave en la comunicación periodística, ya que puede influir en la forma en que los lectores procesan la información y la interpretan. Además, la redacción puede ser un reflejo de la personalidad y la perspectiva del periodista, lo que puede influir en la forma en que los lectores perciben la información y la confían. Por lo tanto, es importante que los periodistas sean conscientes de la importancia de la redacción y la forma en que pueden influir en la percepción de los lectores.

en_results_raw: The others watched him, their faces expressionless, as he walked back and forth across the room, the cigarette dangling from his lips. The air was thick with tension, and the only sound was the soft hum of the clock on the wall. Winston, sitting in the corner, seemed lost in thought, his eyes fixed on some point beyond the window. The others, however, were fully aware of O'Brien's restless energy, and they waited with bated breath for him to speak. His pacing finally came to an end, and he stopped in front of the fireplace, his eyes fixed on the flames dancing in the grate. For a moment, he stood there, his chest heaving slightly, before turning to face the others with a look of determination etched on his face.

es_first_half: Sobre la mesa había una caja de plata con cigarrillos. Con aire distraído, O'Brien la fue acercando a los otros. Tomó él un cigarrillo, se levantó y empezó a pasear por la
es_second_half: habitación como si de este modo pudiera pensar mejor. Eran cigarrillos muy buenos; no se les caía el tabaco y el papel era sedoso. O'Brien volvió a mirar su reloj de pulsera.
es_results: habitación, fumando con una expresión de indiferencia. Los demás lo imitaron, y pronto la habitación se llenó del humo de los cigarrillos. La conversación se volvió más animada,
es_results_raw: habitación, fumando con una expresión de indiferencia. Los demás lo imitaron, y pronto la habitación se llenó del humo de los cigarrillos. La conversación se volvió más animada, y la tensión que había estado presente en el aire comenzó a disminuir. O'Brien se sentó de nuevo en su silla, mirando a los demás con una sonrisa forzada. La caja de plata seguía en la mesa, vacía, excepto por un solo cigarrillo que O'Brien había dejado encendido. La habitación estaba sumida en un silencio incómodo, como si todos estuvieran esperando a que alguien dijera algo. De repente, Winston se levantó y se acercó a la ventana, mirando hacia afuera con una expresión de tristeza. La noche estaba oscura y llena de estrellas, y el viento soplaba suavemente. La habitación parecía estar suspendida en un momento de tiempo, como si el mundo exterior hubiera dejado de existir. La caja de plata seguía en la mesa, un recordatorio de la realidad que se escondía detrás de la fachada de normalidad que habían creado. La tensión en la habitación seguía creciendo, y Winston se dio cuenta de que algo estaba a punto de suceder.

en_first_half: “You will have heard rumors of the existence of the Brotherhood. No doubt you have formed your own picture of it. You have imagined, probably, a huge underworld of conspirators, meeting secretly in cellars, scribbling messages on walls, recognizing one another by code words or by special movements of the hand. Nothing of the kind exists. The members of the Brotherhood have no way of recognizing one another, and it is impossible for any one member to be aware of the identity of more than a very few others. Goldstein himself, if he fell into the hands of the Thought Police, could not give them a complete list of members, or any information that would lead them to a complete list. No such list exists. The Brotherhood cannot be wiped out because it is not an organization in the ordinary sense. Nothing holds it together except an idea which is indestructible. You will never have anything to sustain you except the idea. You will get no comradeship and no encouragement. When finally you are caught, you will
en_second_half: get no help. We never help our members. At most, when it is absolutely necessary that someone should be silenced, we are occasionally able to smuggle a razor blade into a prisoner’s cell. You will have to get used to living without results and without hope. You will work for a while, you will be caught, you will confess, and then you will die. Those are the only results that you will ever see. There is no possibility that any perceptible change will happen within our own lifetime. We are the dead. Our only true life is in the future. We shall take part in it as handfuls of dust and splinters of bone. But how far away that future may be, there is no knowing. It might be a thousand years. At present nothing is possible except to extend the area of sanity little by little. We cannot act collectively. We can only spread our knowledge outwards from individual to individual, generation after generation. In the face of the Thought Police there is no other way.”
en_results: output>The Brotherhood is a mysterious entity that operates in the shadows, its existence a whispered rumor among the population. Its members are scattered, isolated, and unaware of one another's identities, making it nearly impossible for the Thought Police to infiltrate or dismantle. The Brotherhood's power lies not in its structure or hierarchy, but in the unyielding conviction of its adherents. Each member is a solitary figure, driven by a fierce dedication to the cause, and it is this unwavering commitment that sustains them in the face of overwhelming oppression.

en_first_half: By the third day his eyes ached unbearably and his spectacles needed wiping every few minutes. It was like struggling with some crushing physical task, something which one had the right to refuse and which one was nevertheless neurotically anxious to accomplish. In so far as he had time to remember it, he was not troubled by the fact that every word he murmured into the speakwrite, every stroke of his ink pencil, was a deliberate lie. He was as anxious as anyone else in the Department that the forgery should be perfect. On the morning of the sixth day the dribble of cylinders slowed down. For as much as half an hour nothing came out of the tube; then one
en_second_half: more cylinder, then nothing. Everywhere at about the same time the work was easing off. A deep and as it were secret sigh went through the Department. A mighty deed, which could never be mentioned, had been achieved. It was now impossible for any human being to prove by documentary evidence that the war with Eurasia had ever happened. At twelve hundred it was unexpectedly announced that all workers in the Ministry were free till tomorrow morning. Winston, still carrying the brief case containing the book, which had remained between his feet while he worked and under his body while he slept, went home, shaved himself, and almost fell asleep in his bath, although the water was barely more than tepid.
en_results: The machine had finally given up, its exhausted motor sputtering to a halt as the last of the ink trickled out of the tube. The man's eyes, red-rimmed and dry, gazed blankly at the stack of papers in front of him, the rows of neat, identical handwriting a testament to his unwavering dedication to the task at hand. He rubbed his temples, feeling the familiar ache of tension building behind his eyes. en_results_raw: The machine had finally given up, its exhausted motor sputtering to a halt as the last of the ink trickled out of the tube. The man's eyes, red-rimmed and dry, gazed blankly at the stack of papers in front of him, the rows of neat, identical handwriting a testament to his unwavering dedication to the task at hand. He rubbed his temples, feeling the familiar ache of tension building behind his eyes. It was as if he had been staring at the same sentence for hours, the words blurring together into a meaningless jumble of ink and paper. The speakwrite, once a reliable companion in his work, now sat silent and still, its metal body a cold, unforgiving presence on the desk. He reached out a trembling hand to touch the device, as if willing it to come back to life, but it remained stubbornly inert. The silence was oppressive, a heavy weight that pressed down on him, making it hard to breathe. He knew he had to keep going, to keep producing the lies, no matter how much it cost him. The Department was watching, waiting for the results of his labor, and he couldn't afford to disappoint them. Not now, not when he was so close to the end. He took a deep breath, steeling himself for the task ahead, and began to write again, the words flowing out of him in a steady, mechanical rhythm.

La verdad era que había estado esperando con ansias el momento de ver cómo reaccionaría su compañero de habitación, el profesor, cuando le mostrara el resultado de su trabajo. El profesor era un hombre de unos cincuenta años, con una barba larga y despeinada, y una mirada que parecía ver más allá de las cosas. Era un hombre que inspiraba respeto y temor a la vez, y a Juan le gustaba trabajar bajo su supervisión. Mientras esperaba a que el profesor llegara, Juan se puso a revisar su trabajo, buscando cualquier error o fallo que pudiera haber cometido. Pero cuanto más lo revisaba, más seguro se sentía de que todo estaba bien. Había escrito sobre un tema que le interesaba mucho, la historia de la revolución rusa, y había intentado ser lo más objetivo posible, sin dejar que sus propias opiniones influyeran en la narrativa. Cuando el profesor llegó, Juan se levantó de su silla y se acercó a él con la carpeta en la mano. El profesor lo miró con una expresión seria, y Juan se sintió un poco nervioso. "¿Qué tal?" preguntó el profesor, sin darle tiempo a Juan de hablar. Juan se aclaró la garganta y comenzó a explicar su trabajo, intentando ser lo más claro posible. El profesor lo escuchó atentamente, sin interrumpirlo ni una sola vez. Cuando Juan terminó, el profesor se quedó en silencio durante un momento, como si estuviera pensando en algo. Luego, se levantó y se acercó a la ventana, mirando hacia afuera. Juan se sintió un poco incómodo, no sabiendo qué esperar. Finalmente, el profesor se dio la vuelta y se acercó a Juan, sonriendo. "Buen trabajo, Juan", dijo. "Parece que has hecho un buen esfuerzo. Pero hay algo que me preocupa". Juan se sintió un poco aliviado, pensando que el profesor iba a decirle que todo estaba bien. Pero entonces el profesor agregó: "¿Qué es lo que realmente crees sobre la revolución rusa?" Juan se sintió sorprendido. No había esperado esa pregunta. Había intentado ser objetivo, pero sabía que no había podido evitar dejar algunas de sus propias opiniones en el texto. "Bueno", dijo, intentando pensar en la respuesta, "creo que la revolución rusa fue un momento importante en la historia, pero también un momento de gran violencia y caos". El profesor asintió con la cabeza. "Sí, eso es cierto. Pero ¿qué crees que fue lo que realmente motivó a los bolcheviques a tomar el poder?" Juan se sintió un poco perdido. No había pensado en eso antes. "Bueno", dijo, intentando pensar en la respuesta, "creo que fue la desigualdad económica y la falta de oportunidades para la clase trabajadora". El profesor sonrió. "Exactamente. La desigualdad económica y la falta de oportunidades para la clase trabajadora fueron los motores de la revolución. Pero también hay algo más, algo que no mencionaste en tu texto". Juan se sintió intrigado. "¿Qué es?" preguntó. El profesor se acercó a él y le susurró: "La ambición. La ambición de Lenin y de los bolcheviques de tomar el poder y crear un nuevo orden". Juan se sintió sorprendido. No había pensado en eso antes. La ambición de Lenin y de los bolcheviques. Era algo que no había considerado en su texto. Pero ahora que lo pensaba, parecía obvio. La ambición de Lenin y de los bolcheviques había sido el motor de la revolución, y había llevado a la creación de un nuevo orden en Rusia. Juan se sintió un poco avergonzado de no haber pensado en eso antes. Pero también se sintió agradecido por la lección del profesor. Había aprendido algo nuevo, algo que lo haría pensar de manera diferente sobre la historia. Y eso era lo que importaba, no la perfección de su texto, sino

en_first_half: “It was my little daughter,” said Parsons with a sort of doleful pride. “She listened at the keyhole. Heard what I was saying, and nipped off to the patrols the very next day.
en_second_half: Pretty smart for a nipper of seven, eh? I don’t bear her any grudge for it. In fact I’m proud of her. It shows I brought her up in the right spirit, anyway.”
en_results: She must have been frightened by what she heard, and I suppose it's only natural that she would go to the authorities, but it's hard for me to see it that way.
en_results_raw: She must have been frightened by what she heard, and I suppose it's only natural that she would go to the authorities, but it's hard for me to see it that way. I mean, I'm a respected member of this community, and the thought of my own daughter turning me in is a bitter pill to swallow. I've always tried to be a good father to her, to teach her right from wrong, but I suppose I must have failed in some way. The patrols were at our doorstep before I even knew what was happening, and they took me away in handcuffs, leaving my poor daughter alone and scared. I've been in here for what feels like an eternity, and I've had time to think about what I did, to think about the consequences of my actions. I've come to realize that I was wrong, that I let my own selfish desires cloud my judgment, and I'm truly sorry for it. But I'm not sure if it's enough, if it's enough to make up for what I've done. I just hope that my daughter can find it in her heart to forgive me, to understand that I'm not a bad person, just a flawed one.

en_first_half: The door opened, and another prisoner was brought in whose appearance sent a momentary chill through Winston. He was a commonplace, mean-looking man who might have been an engineer or technician of some kind. But what was
en_second_half: startling was the emaciation of his face. It was like a skull. Because of its thinness the mouth and eyes looked disproportionately large, and the eyes seemed filled with a murderous, unappeasable hatred of somebody or something.
en_results: unmistakable about him was the look of a man who had been broken, his eyes sunken, his face pale and gaunt, and his movements listless and hesitant. He was thrown into the cell across from Winston, and the door slammed shut behind
en_results_raw: unmistakable about him was the look of a man who had been broken, his eyes sunken, his face pale and gaunt, and his movements listless and hesitant. He was thrown into the cell across from Winston, and the door slammed shut behind him, plunging the small room into an oppressive silence. Winston watched him with a mixture of curiosity and unease, trying to read the story behind the man's defeated expression. The prisoner's eyes met Winston's for a brief moment, and he looked away, his gaze drifting to the floor as if ashamed. Winston's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of footsteps outside, and the door creaked open once more. A guard entered, a cruel smile spreading across his face as he addressed the new prisoner in a voice that was both menacing and condescending. "Welcome to your new home," he sneered, his eyes glinting with malice. The prisoner's eyes flickered up, and for an instant, Winston saw a glimmer of defiance, but it was quickly extinguished, replaced by a look of resignation. The guard turned to Winston, his expression softening slightly as he spoke in a more neutral tone, "And you, Winston, are still waiting for your trial. The waiting game continues." The door closed, and the silence was once again oppressive, punctuated only by the sound of the prisoners' labored breathing.

Đôi mắt của hắn trông quá nhạy cảm, quá thông minh, như thể hắn đang nhìn thấy được mọi thứ mà Winston không thể nhìn thấy được. Winston cảm thấy một luồng gió lạnh chạy qua người mình, và hắn biết rằng mình đã gặp được một người đặc biệt. Người đàn ông này không phải là một phạm nhân bình thường, và Winston biết rằng mình sẽ phải tìm hiểu thêm về hắn. Hắn bắt đầu suy nghĩ về những câu hỏi mà mình sẽ đặt cho người đàn ông này, và những câu trả lời mà mình sẽ nhận được. Hắn biết rằng cuộc trò chuyện này sẽ không dễ dàng, nhưng hắn cũng biết rằng mình phải cố gắng. Winston nhìn người đàn ông này một lần nữa, và thấy được sự tự tin trong đôi mắt của hắn. Hắn biết rằng mình đã gặp được một người có thể giúp mình tìm ra sự thật, và hắn sẵn sàng để bắt đầu cuộc hành trình này.

en_results_raw: The doctor's voice was a distant hum, a soothing melody that seemed to be coming from far away. Winston's mind was a jumble of fragmented thoughts, each one slipping away like sand between his fingers. He tried to grasp at them, to hold on to something, anything, but they dissolved into nothingness. The pain was a constant, a throbbing drumbeat that echoed through his skull. He felt a cold sweat break out on his forehead, and his body trembled with a mixture of fear and exhaustion. The fingers behind his eyelids continued their maddening dance, their movements a blur of black and white, like a film reel spinning out of control. Winston's breath came in short gasps, and his heart pounded in his chest like a jackhammer. He was trapped in a nightmare from which he couldn't wake up, and the pain was the only constant, the only reality. The doctor's voice grew louder, more insistent, but Winston couldn't make out the words. He was lost in a sea of agony, adrift in a world that seemed to be spinning out of control.

es_results_raw: en el suelo, con la espalda apoyada en algo frío y duro. Al principio, no supo qué era lo que había sucedido, pero a medida que sus sentidos comenzaron a recuperarse, recordó que había estado caminando por el parque, disfrutando del fresco de la noche, cuando de repente sintió un golpe en la espalda. Al levantar la vista, vio que había sido empujado por un hombre alto y delgado, con una cara pálida y ojos que parecían ver a través de él. El hombre había desaparecido en la oscuridad, dejándolo solo en el suelo, con la sensación de que algo había cambiado en su vida. La oscuridad parecía haberse vuelto más oscura, y el silencio más silencioso. Winston se levantó lentamente, intentando procesar lo que había sucedido. ¿Quién era ese hombre, y qué quería de él? ¿Era un sueño, o una realidad? La incertidumbre lo envolvía como una niebla, y no sabía qué camino tomar. Mientras se levantaba, notó que su mano derecha estaba manchada de sangre. ¿Era suya, o de alguien más? La sangre parecía fresca, y él no recordaba haberse herido. La confusión y la desorientación lo envolvían, y no sabía qué hacer a continuación. Se quedó allí, inmóvil, intentando recordar lo que había sucedido, pero sus recuerdos parecían estar borrosos y confusos. La oscuridad parecía estar cerrándose a su alrededor, y él se sentía cada vez más aislado y solo. De repente, escuchó un ruido en la distancia, un ruido que parecía provenir de una de las casas cercanas. Era un ruido débil, pero lo suficientemente claro como para hacer que Winston se sintiera un poco más seguro. Se levantó y comenzó a caminar hacia el ruido, intentando encontrar refugio y seguridad en un lugar desconocido.

You are fed a constant stream of propaganda, and your thoughts are monitored and controlled. You are encouraged to report any suspicious behavior or thoughts, and those who fail to comply are dealt with swiftly and severely. Understanding comes next, where you begin to see the world through the Party's eyes and start to question your own thoughts and feelings. You begin to realize that your memories of the past are false, and that your entire life has been a lie. You start to see the Party as the only truth, and the rebels as enemies of the state. And finally, there is acceptance, where you fully surrender to the Party's ideology and become a loyal citizen, willing to do whatever it takes to maintain the Party's power and control.

en_results_raw: The streets are filled with the sounds of scurrying feet and the stench of rotting garbage, a constant reminder of the harsh realities of life in the underbelly of this city. The rats, with their beady eyes and razor-sharp teeth, roam freely, scavenging for food in the dark alleys and abandoned buildings. They are a testament to the resilience of nature, thriving in the shadows of human neglect and indifference. But, as O'Brien's words dripped with malice, he knew that the rats were more than just a nuisance, they were a symptom of a far greater problem, a problem that threatened to consume them all. The rats, with their ability to adapt and survive in the most inhospitable environments, were a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there was always a glimmer of hope, a glimmer that O'Brien was determined to extinguish. His eyes gleamed with a sinister intensity as he continued to speak, his voice dripping with venom, "And it is here, in this very city, that we will find the key to our revolution, a revolution that will bring about a new era of peace and prosperity, or so we are told." The crowd, entranced by O'Brien's words, hung on his every sentence, their faces a mask of devotion, their eyes burning with a fervor that bordered on fanaticism. But, as the sun began to set, casting long shadows across the city, a sense of unease settled over the crowd, a sense that something was not quite right, that the revolution O'Brien spoke of was not as glorious as it seemed.

en_results: The rats were trying to get to the food that had been left out overnight, but one of them, a large and aggressive male, was fiercely
en_results_raw: The rats were trying to get to the food that had been left out overnight, but one of them, a large and aggressive male, was fiercely defending his territory and refusing to let the others get near it. The commotion was so loud that it echoed through the entire laboratory, causing the scientists to rush to the scene to intervene and separate the fighting animals. As they arrived, they were met with a chaotic sight: the rats were scurrying around in all directions, their tiny paws waving in the air as they chased each other in a frenzy of squeaks and squeals. The scientists quickly sprang into action, carefully scooping up the rats and placing them back into their cages, trying to restore order to the laboratory and prevent any further disturbances. But as they worked, they couldn't help but notice that one of the rats seemed different from the others - it was larger and more aggressive than the rest, and it seemed to be the source of the trouble. The scientists exchanged curious glances, wondering what could have caused this unusual behavior in one of their normally docile subjects.

en_first_half: Winston’s heart stirred. That was the bulletin from the front; instinct told him that it was bad news that was coming. All day, with little spurts of excitement, the thought of a smashing defeat in Africa had been in and out of his mind. He seemed actually to see the Eurasian army swarming across the never-broken frontier and pouring down into the tip of Africa like a column of ants. Why had it not been possible to outflank them in some way? The outline of the West African coast stood out vividly in his mind. He picked up the white knight and moved it across the board. There was the proper spot. Even while he saw the black
en_second_half: horde racing southward he saw another force, mysteriously assembled, suddenly planted in their rear, cutting their communications by land and sea. He felt that by willing it he was bringing that other force into existence. But it was necessary to act quickly. If they could get control of the whole of Africa, if they had airfields and submarine bases at the Cape, it would cut Oceania in two. It might mean anything: defeat, breakdown, the redivision of the world, the destruction of the Party! He drew a deep breath. An extraordinary medley of feelings—but it was not a medley, exactly; rather it was successive layers of feeling, in which one could not say which layer was undermost—struggled inside him.
en_results: output>pieces moving forward, he felt a strange sense of calm wash over him. It was as if he had been given a glimpse of a solution to the puzzle that had been plaguing him all day. He studied the board intently, his mind racing with the possibilities. The white knight, now in its new position, seemed to be pointing to a weakness in the enemy's line. He could almost see the black pieces faltering, their advance slowing as they struggled to respond to the sudden shift in the game. Winston's heart was pounding in his chest, but it was no longer with anxiety. Instead, it was with excitement and a sense of purpose. He felt a surge of confidence, as if he had finally grasped the key to winning the game.

en_first_half: It must have been about a month before she disappeared. It was a moment of reconciliation, when the nagging hunger in his belly was forgotten and his earlier affection for her had temporarily revived. He remembered the day well, a pelting, drenching day when the water streamed down the window pane and the light indoors was too dull to read by. The boredom of the two children in the dark, cramped bedroom became unbearable. Winston whined and grizzled, made futile demands for food, fretted about the room, pulling everything out of place and kicking the wainscoting until the neighbors banged on the wall, while the younger child wailed intermittently. In the end his mother said, “Now be good, and I’ll buy you a toy. A lovely toy—you’ll love it”; and then she had gone out in the rain, to a little general shop which was still sporadically open near by, and come
en_second_half: back with a cardboard box containing an outfit of Snakes and Ladders. He could still remember the smell of the damp cardboard. It was a miserable outfit. The board was cracked and the tiny wooden dice were so ill-cut that they would hardly lie on their sides. Winston looked at the thing sulkily and without interest. But then his mother lit a piece of candle and they sat down on the floor to play. Soon he was wildly excited and shouting with laughter as the tiddlywinks climbed hopefully up the ladders and then came slithering down the snakes again, almost back to the starting point. They played eight games, winning four each. His tiny sister, too young to understand what the game was about, had sat propped up against a bolster, laughing because the others were laughing. For a whole afternoon they had all been happy together, as in his earlier childhood.

The children's eyes widened as she handed it to Winston, who immediately began to fiddle with the lid, trying to figure out how it opened. His mother smiled and sat down beside him, patiently guiding his small fingers as he struggled to align the pieces. The younger child, sensing the excitement, ceased wailing and crept closer, watching with wide eyes as the puzzle box slowly yielded to Winston's persistence. The sound of rain drumming against the windowpane created a soothing background hum, and for a moment, the cramped, dark room was filled with a sense of possibility and joy. The mother's earlier exhaustion seemed to melt away, replaced by a warmth and contentment that she hadn't felt in weeks. As the children played with the puzzle box, their laughter and chatter filled the air, and the mother felt a glimmer of hope that things might get better, that they might somehow find a way to make ends meet and start anew. But as the afternoon wore on, the rain showed no signs of letting up, and the mother knew that the struggle was far from over. She glanced out the window, watching as the rain-soaked streets glistened in the dim light, and a shiver ran down her spine. It was then that she noticed a figure standing under the awning of the little general shop, a figure that seemed to be watching her. The mother's heart skipped a beat as she felt a sense of unease wash over her. Who was this person, and what did they want? She tried to brush it off as mere paranoia, but the feeling lingered, and she found herself glancing back at the figure several times, her mind racing with possibilities. As the rain continued to fall, the mother's anxiety grew, and she couldn't shake the feeling that something was off, that this moment of reconciliation was about to be shattered by some unseen force. Little did she know, her life was about to take a drastic turn, one that would change everything forever.

Fueron unos momentos de reconciliación en que Winston no sentía aquel hambre imperiosa y le había vuelto temporalmente el cariño por su madre. Recordaba bien aquel día, un día húmedo de lluvia continua. El agua chorreaba monótona por los cristales de las ventanas y la luz del interior era demasiado débil para leer. El aburrimiento de los dos niños en la triste habitación era insoportable. Winston gimoteaba, pedía inútilmente que le dieran de comer, recorría la habitación revolviéndolo todo y dando patadas hasta que los vecinos tuvieron que protestar.
